metadata.titleEn: Surface DEM for typical glaciers on the Tibetan Plateau (Version 1.0) (2003)
metadata.description:
The DEMs of the typical glaciers on the Tibetan Plateau were provided by the bistatic InSAR method. The data were collected on November 21, 2013. It covered Puruogangri and west Qilian Mountains with a spatial resolution of 10 meters, and an elevation accuracy of 0.8 m which met the requirements of national 1:10 000 topographic mapping. Considering the characteristics of the bistatic InSAR in terms of imaging geometry and phase unwrapping, based on the TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data, and adopting the improved SAR interference processing method, the surface DEMs of the two typical glaciers above were generated with high resolution and precision. The data set was in GeoTIFF format, and each typical glacial DEM was stored in a folder.
For details of the data, please refer to the Surface DEMs for typical glaciers on the Tibetan Plateau - Data Description.

background: Spaceborne SAR interferometry (SAR interferometry, InSAR) is one of the most effective technologies for global large-scale topographic mapping and Earth observation. In 2000, the U.S. Space Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) demonstrated the outstanding performance of dual-station InSAR technology in topographic mapping. With the development of spaceborne SAR data acquisition capabilities and multi-baseline InSAR analysis methods, repeat-pass InSAR technology has also been increasingly refined for topographic mapping. As a continuation of the X-SAR/SRTM program, the German Aerospace Center (DLR) and Astrium GmbH jointly implemented the TanDEM-X scientific program, with the primary goal of obtaining global HRTI-3 standard DEMs. The TanDEM-X dual-station SAR consists of the TerraSAR-X (TSX) satellite and the TanDEM-X (TDX) satellite, forming a dual-station SAR interferometry system that achieves spaceborne dual-station SAR interferometry for the first time. Due to the dual-station observation mode's ability to effectively eliminate the effects of atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation, this technology has significant advantages and broad application prospects in the field of high-resolution and high-precision DEM mapping on a global scale.
research objective: This article proposes a high-precision terrain extraction method based on TanDEM-X dual-station SAR data and uses ICESat laser altimetry data for accuracy assessment. It presents a method for generating DEM using TanDEM-X dual-station InSAR, which mainly includes the strategy of introducing external DEM for phase differencing to reduce phase residuals and improve phase unwrapping accuracy and efficiency.
challenges: However, due to the weak radar echo signals in glacier areas, rapid changes in the ice and snow surface, and the effects of temporal decorrelation caused by glacier movement, repeat-pass InSAR has difficulty obtaining high-resolution and high-precision glacier topography data.
methods: The TanDEM-X dual-station SAR data used in this experiment is in the dual-station stripmap mode, which is a commonly used data acquisition mode for generating DEMs. The terrain extraction method proposed in this paper using TanDEM-X dual-station InSAR has a data processing workflow that is basically consistent with conventional InSAR, including SAR image registration, interferogram generation, interferogram filtering, phase unwrapping, and phase-to-elevation conversion. In the specific data processing, the azimuth and range looks are both set to 5 according to the radar imaging characteristics of the TSX/TDX satellites and the DEM resolution requirements, resulting in an azimuth resolution of 16.5 m and a range resolution of 12.6 m for the interferogram. The filtering method used is the Goldstein Filter, which has good denoising effects while preserving the integrity of the interferometric fringes. The phase unwrapping employs the minimum cost flow (MCF) method, which balances computational speed and accuracy.
dataset: The experimental area is located in the central part of the Tibetan Plateau, specifically the Puruogangri Glacier, covering an area of approximately 423 km². The glacier snow line elevation ranges from 5,620 to 5,860 meters. A pair of TanDEM-X dual station SAR data was acquired from this region on January 26, 2012, with the data format being coregistered single look slant range complex (CoSSC). ICESat/GLA14 satellite altimetry data was used to calibrate and assess the accuracy of the TanDEM-X DEM results. The vertical accuracy of the ICESat altimetry data is ±13.8 cm, with a horizontal accuracy better than 20 cm. The laser beam forms a spot with a diameter of approximately 70 meters on the ground, and the spacing between points in the strips is about 170 meters.
findings: Taking the complex terrain environment of the Purogangri Glacier as an example, a DEM with a spatial resolution of 10 m and an elevation accuracy of 0.8 m was obtained, meeting the requirements for national 1:10,000 topographic mapping. High-precision ICESat elevation data were used for accuracy assessment, achieving the standards for national 1:10,000 DEM topographic mapping. This preliminarily verifies the capability of this technology in DEM mapping in complex terrain areas, as well as its global terrain extraction value and application prospects.

background: Accurate measurements of glacier surface topography and their changes play an essential role in various glaciological studies related to glacier dynamics and mass balance.
research objective: The focus of this study is on mapping glacier digital elevation model (DEM) and elevation changes in the western Qilian Mountains, northern Tibetan Plateau, by synergistically using the TanDEM-X (TDX) bistatic Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) data in 2013 and Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) DEM in 2000.
challenges: A major challenge in using digital photogrammetry to map glacier surface topography is that the glacier surface should have sufficient radiometric and/or topographic heterogeneity in image pairs. However, it is difficult for these LiDAR systems to acquire topographic datasets over large-scale glaciated regions, because of political sensitivities (e.g., Karakoram), high costs, and poor archiving. However, this repeat-pass InSAR is still challenging for glacier applications because it commonly suffers from atmospheric disturbance (mainly due to variations of the troposphere and the ionosphere between the repeat-pass SAR acquisitions), as well as temporal decorrelation induced by ice melting, snow accumulation and glacier movement between acquisitions.
methods: The first high-resolution and high-precision glacier DEM is derived in this region by a TDX InSAR procedure with a nonlocal (NL) filter. Validated against the Ice, Cloud, and land Elevation Satellite (ICESat) height references, the absolute height error of the TanDEM-X DEM derived with the NL filter and the Goldstein filter with the parameters investigated is, respectively, 1.493 ± 0.747 and 1.857 ± 1.709 m. Further, four combinations of differential phase method (DiffPha) and DEM differencing method (DiffDem) with Goldstein filter and NL filter are applied to estimate glacier elevation changes between 2000 and 2013.
dataset: In this study, one pair of TSX/TDX SAR data in bistatic strip-map mode acquired on 21 November 2013 was used to generate high-resolution and high-precision TDX DEM. In this study, the SRTM-C DEM with 1 arc s spatial resolution (about 30 m) was used to generate simulated topographic phase and to estimate glacier elevation changes with TanDEM-X InSAR data. ICESat laser altimeter data were used as height reference data to assess vertical accuracy of the InSAR-derived TDX DEM in 2013. A total of 121 GPS points were surveyed and obtained high-accuracy glacier elevation measurements (vertical precision of ±0.2 m).
findings: Generally, a clear surface thinning can be found in most glacier tongue regions, the maximum value of elevation lowering up to approximately − 40 m, whereas a slight thickening is detected in accumulation areas, which are in agreement with the height difference results between GPS measurements and SRTM DEM over Laohugou Glacier No.12. This study demonstrates the potential of the TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR in mapping surface topography and elevation changes of valley glaciers in the Tibetan Plateau.

Verification.Question: Can bistatic InSAR data processing techniques provide high-resolution and high-precision glacier DEMs?
Do atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation pose challenges for repeat-pass InSAR glacier mapping applications?
Is the ICESat laser altimeter data used for accuracy assessment of InSAR-derived glacier DEMs?

Disjunctive.Question: Which filtering technique is better for maintaining the integrity of interferometric fringes in SAR data processing: Goldstein filter or another type of filter?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that effectively addresses the challenge of atmospheric disturbance in glacier DEM mapping?
Example.Answer: The TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR system is an example that effectively mitigates atmospheric disturbances by utilizing a dual-satellite configuration, which helps eliminate atmospheric influences and temporal decorrelation issues that typically affect repeat-pass InSAR techniques.

Example.Question: What is an example of a technological advancement that has improved the precision of glacier surface topography measurements?
Example.Answer: An example of technological advancement is the use of the TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data, which provides high-resolution and high-precision glacier DEM by employing advanced filters like the Goldstein filter and nonlocal (NL) filter to enhance data accuracy.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset used for validating high-precision glacier DEM results?
Example.Answer: ICESat laser altimeter data is an example of a dataset used to validate the vertical accuracy of high-precision glacier DEM results obtained from TanDEM-X InSAR data, ensuring the DEM's precision aligns with expected standards.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of high-precision glacier DEMs generated using bistatic InSAR data?
Feature Specification.Answer: 10 meters spatial resolution, 0.8 meters elevation accuracy, TanDEM-X data, advanced processing techniques, national mapping standards compliance, 1:10,000 scale in China

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges in collecting high-resolution glacier topography data using InSAR techniques?
Feature Specification.Answer: weak radar echo signals, rapid changes in ice and snow surfaces, temporal decorrelation, atmospheric disturbances from the troposphere and ionosphere

Feature Specification.Question: What types of reference data are used to validate the accuracy of InSAR-derived DEMs in glaciated areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: ±13.8 cm vertical accuracy, better than 20 cm horizontal accuracy, ±0.2 m vertical precision

Quantification.Question: What is the elevation precision achieved in generating DEMs using TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data for glaciers on the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is bistatic Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) and how is it used in glacier DEM mapping?
Definition.Answer: Bistatic Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) refers to the use of two satellites, such as the TerraSAR-X (TSX) and TanDEM-X (TDX), to create a SAR interferometry system. This system can effectively eliminate atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation effects, which are common challenges in glacier applications. It is used in glacier DEM mapping to generate high-resolution and high-precision digital elevation models (DEMs), capable of capturing elevation changes and surface topography of glacier regions.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with using repeat-pass InSAR for glacier surface topography mapping?
Definition.Answer: Repeat-pass InSAR for glacier surface topography mapping faces challenges such as atmospheric disturbances due to variations in the troposphere and ionosphere between repeat-pass SAR acquisitions. Additionally, temporal decorrelation caused by ice melting, snow accumulation, and glacier movement between acquisitions makes it difficult to acquire accurate topographic datasets over large-scale glaciated regions.

Definition.Question: How can ICESat laser altimeter data be utilized in the evaluation of InSAR-derived DEMs in glaciological studies?
Definition.Answer: ICESat laser altimeter data can be used as height reference data to assess the vertical accuracy of InSAR-derived DEMs. These data provide high-precision elevation measurements, allowing for accurate evaluation of the DEM's absolute height error, which is crucial for validating the results of glacier surface topography and elevation changes derived from InSAR data.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges in acquiring high-resolution glacier topography data using TanDEM-X InSAR compare to those faced by digital photogrammetry techniques?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges using TanDEM-X InSAR mainly involve temporal decorrelation due to ice melting, snow accumulation, and glacier movement, as well as atmospheric disturbances. Digital photogrammetry, on the other hand, requires sufficient radiometric and/or topographic heterogeneity in image pairs, which can be difficult to achieve over large-scale glaciated regions due to political sensitivities, high costs, and poor archiving.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the methods for processing TanDEM-X InSAR data differ when comparing the use of NL filter and Goldstein filter for deriving glacier DEMs?
Comparison.Answer: The methods differ in their approach to filtering; the NL filter and Goldstein filter are both used, but they result in different absolute height errors. The NL filter results in an absolute height error of 1.493 ± 0.747 m, while the Goldstein filter results in an error of 1.857 ± 1.709 m. Furthermore, they are applied in combinations with differential phase and DEM differencing methods to estimate elevation changes.

Interpretation.Question: What interpretation can be made about the effectiveness of bistatic InSAR data in overcoming atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation in glacier topography mapping?
Interpretation.Answer: Bistatic InSAR data is effective in overcoming atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation in glacier topography mapping by employing the dual-satellite TanDEM-X system, which reduces atmospheric effects and time-related decorrelation. The high precision and resolution of the DEM generated demonstrate its capability in complex terrain mapping, meeting the accuracy requirements for detailed topographic studies.

Interpretation.Question: How do improvements in phase unwrapping and filtering techniques contribute to the accuracy of digital elevation models in glaciated regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Improvements in phase unwrapping and filtering techniques, such as the use of the Goldstein filter and the minimum cost flow method, enhance the accuracy of digital elevation models by reducing phase residuals and improving phase unwrapping precision and efficiency. These methodologies are crucial for achieving high resolution and precision in DEMs, particularly in areas with complex topography like glaciated regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty of acquiring high-resolution and high-precision glacier topography data using digital photogrammetry in large-scale glaciated regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty arises because the glacier surface must have sufficient radiometric and/or topographic heterogeneity in image pairs. Additionally, challenges include political sensitivities, high costs, poor archiving, and atmospheric disturbances such as variations in the troposphere and ionosphere, as well as temporal decorrelation due to ice melting, snow accumulation, and glacier movement between acquisitions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is repeat-pass InSAR technology challenging for obtaining high-resolution glacier topography data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Repeat-pass InSAR technology is challenging because it is susceptible to atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation. These disturbances are mainly due to variations in the troposphere and ionosphere, while temporal decorrelation is induced by ice melting, snow accumulation, and glacier movement between acquisitions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes errors or challenges in generating digital elevation models (DEMs) of glaciers using TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors or challenges in generating DEMs of glaciers using TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data are caused by weak radar echo signals in glacier regions, rapid changes on ice and snow surfaces, and time decorrelation effects due to glacier movement. These factors make it difficult to obtain high-resolution and high-precision data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of utilizing TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data for glacier surface topography mapping when considering challenges such as atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data can lead to high-resolution and high-precision glacier DEMs, despite challenges like atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation. This approach effectively reduces atmospheric and temporal noise, providing valuable insights into glacier elevation changes and surface topography, as demonstrated by its application in the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of ICESat laser altimeter data into TanDEM-X InSAR processing influence the accuracy of glacier DEMs?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating ICESat laser altimeter data provides a reliable height reference, enhancing the vertical accuracy of glacier DEMs derived from TanDEM-X InSAR data. The use of high-precision ICESat data aids in calibrating and validating the InSAR-derived DEMs, ensuring their precision meets national topographic mapping standards.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop high-precision glacier digital elevation models using advanced SAR techniques in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing high-precision glacier DEMs using advanced SAR techniques is crucial due to the complex terrain and dynamic glacier changes in the Tibetan Plateau. These models play an essential role in glaciological studies, particularly in understanding glacier dynamics and mass balance. The high-resolution and high-precision data obtained through these techniques can significantly enhance the accuracy of topographic measurements and provide valuable insights into the spatial and temporal changes in glacier surfaces.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary challenges faced by researchers when collecting high-resolution topographic data over glaciated regions, and how can these challenges be addressed using current technologies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: One of the primary challenges in collecting high-resolution topographic data over glaciated regions is the weak radar echo signals and fast-changing ice and snow surfaces, which lead to atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation. These challenges can be addressed using bistatic SAR modes, like TanDEM-X, which effectively reduce atmospheric and temporal decorrelation effects. Additionally, combining SAR data with external datasets, such as ICESat laser altimeter data, can enhance accuracy and provide reliable references for calibration and validation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in generating a high-resolution glacier digital elevation model (DEM) using TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data, and how is accuracy assessed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps to generate a high-resolution glacier DEM using TanDEM-X bistatic InSAR data involve a TDX InSAR procedure with a nonlocal (NL) filter. The process includes SAR image registration, interferogram generation, interferogram filtering using the Goldstein Filter, phase unwrapping, and conversion from phase to elevation. The accuracy is assessed by validating the DEM against ICESat height references, with the absolute height error of the DEM being measured.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the primary challenges faced when using repeat-pass InSAR methods for glacier surface topography mapping, and what strategies can be employed to overcome these challenges?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The primary challenges with repeat-pass InSAR methods for glacier surface topography mapping include atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation due to ice melting, snow accumulation, and glacier movement. Strategies to overcome these challenges involve using bistatic SAR modes that can minimize atmospheric effects and employing advanced filtering techniques like the Goldstein and nonlocal (NL) filters to improve data quality and precision.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the generation of high-resolution digital elevation models (DEMs) in glaciated regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of TanDEM-X bistatic Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) data, particularly in bistatic strip-map mode, enables the generation of high-resolution and high-precision DEMs in glaciated regions by effectively handling atmospheric disturbance and temporal decorrelation challenges.

Enablement.Question: How do specific filtering methods enhance the accuracy of digital elevation models in complex terrain?
Enablement.Answer: The implementation of nonlocal (NL) filters and Goldstein filters in the TanDEM-X InSAR data processing enhances the accuracy of digital elevation models by minimizing phase noise and improving phase unwrapping accuracy, leading to high-precision results validated against ICESat height references.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the integration of external height reference data contribute to the accuracy assessment of InSAR-derived DEMs?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of ICESat laser altimeter data as height reference data allows for an accurate assessment of vertical accuracy in InSAR-derived DEMs. This validation process ensures that the height error is minimized, thereby validating the precision of DEMs produced in challenging glaciated regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to acquire high-resolution and high-precision glacier surface topography data over large-scale regions using digital photogrammetry?
Expectation.Answer: A major challenge in using digital photogrammetry to map glacier surface topography is that the glacier surface should have sufficient radiometric and/or topographic heterogeneity in image pairs. Additionally, it is difficult for certain systems to acquire topographic datasets over large-scale glaciated regions due to political sensitivities, high costs, and poor archiving. Furthermore, repeat-pass InSAR, commonly used for such data collection, suffers from atmospheric disturbances and temporal decorrelation due to ice melting, snow accumulation, and glacier movement between acquisitions.

Expectation.Question: What factors could influence the precision and accuracy of glacier DEMs generated using bistatic InSAR techniques?
Expectation.Answer: The precision and accuracy of glacier DEMs generated using bistatic InSAR techniques can be influenced by the choice of filtering methods, such as the nonlocal (NL) filter and the Goldstein filter. The absolute height error of TanDEM-X DEMs can vary depending on these parameters. Moreover, atmospheric disturbances, temporal decorrelation due to glacier surface changes, and the effectiveness of processing methods like differential phase and DEM differencing methods can also impact the results.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges associated with collecting accurate glacier topography data using InSAR techniques?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include dealing with weak radar echo signals, rapid changes in ice and snow surfaces, and temporal decorrelation due to glacier movement. Additionally, atmospheric disturbances such as variations in the troposphere and ionosphere between repeat-pass SAR acquisitions pose significant hurdles in obtaining accurate glacier topography data using InSAR techniques.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how high-resolution glacier surface topography data is collected and processed using InSAR technology.
Assertion.Answer: High-resolution glacier surface topography data is collected using TanDEM-X bistatic Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) technology. This involves using SAR data in a bistatic strip-map mode and processing it with methods such as SAR image registration, interferogram generation, filtering, phase unwrapping, and converting phase data to elevation. Techniques like using nonlocal (NL) filters or Goldstein filters help in refining the precision and resolution of the derived Digital Elevation Models (DEMs).

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges faced when using InSAR data for mapping glacier elevations over large-scale regions.
Assertion.Answer: One of the main challenges when using InSAR data for mapping glacier elevations is dealing with atmospheric disturbances, particularly due to variations in the troposphere and ionosphere between repeat-pass SAR acquisitions. Additionally, temporal decorrelation caused by ice melting, snow accumulation, and glacier movement can affect the accuracy of the data. Obtaining topographic datasets over large-scale glaciated regions is also complicated by political sensitivities, high costs, and difficulties in data archiving.
